The gas diffusion process is very energy intensive. For 
each 5.5 kg of UF6 at a natural circulation of 0.71% U-235, 
the process produces 1 kg of UF6 enriched to 4.3% U-235 
and 4.5 kg of UF6 depleted to 0.2% U-235.
Alternatively, centrifuge technology has gained favor 
in a number of countries. In the centrifuge enrichment 
process, the gaseous UF6 is put into a cylindrical container 
(centrifuge) that spins the material at high speeds. The 
heavier U-238 atoms are flung to the outside of the 
centrifuge leaving the UF6 in the center enriched with a 
higher proportion of U-235. A single centrifuge will not 
achieve the necessary enrichment levels; therefore, it 
is necessary to connect a series of centrifuges together 
in a cascade. The enrichment is gradually increased to 
the desired level in the 3 to 5 wt% range necessary for 
currently operating commercial nuclear power plants. The 
centrifuge process requires only about 2% of the energy 
needed for a gaseous diffusion plant to achieve the same 
level of enrichment.
Recent efforts have focused upon the development 
of lasers for use in various enrichment processes. In 
this process, requiring even less energy, photons are 
used to separate the desirable U-235 isotopes from the 
more abundant but nonfissile U-238 isotopes found in 
natural uranium. A full production facility has yet to 
begin commercial operation in the U.S. Some concerns 
have been raised with regard to nonproliferation and 
the laser process, which has contributed to the delay of 
commercialization.
Enrichment services are sold in separative work 
units (SWU). The SWU represents the energy required 
to separate U-235 and U-238. The uranium enrichment 
level depends on the amount of uranium feed, the amount 
of SWU used, and the desired U-235 concentration. If the 
price of uranium is relatively low, then more uranium and 
less SWU will be used. Conversely, if the price of uranium 
is relatively high, then less uranium and more SWU will 
be used to reach the desired U-235 concentration.
Fuel Fabrication
Nuclear fuel fabrication is the final step in producing 
uranium fuel for commercial light water nuclear power 
reactors. During fabrication, UF6 (typically enriched to 
between 3 and 5% U-235) is converted to UO2 powder. A 
ceramic process is then used to convert the UO2 powder 
to pellets, which are mechanically loaded into metal rods. 
The metal rods are then loaded into fuel assemblies, which 
typically include Inconel® upper and lower end spacer grids, 
zircaloy-based intermediate spacer grids, and stainless 
steel nozzles as shown in Fig. 4. Manufacturing these 
components and integrating them into a fuel assembly 
require special methods and processes. Other combina­
tions of Inconel and zircaloy-based grids may also be used.
Conversion to UO2 powder
Once enriched, UF6 is converted to UO2 for use in 
making the fuel pellets. Conversion to UO2 is accomplished

by either a dry or wet process. For the dry method, UF6 
is heated to a vapor and fed into a two-stage rotary kiln 
(reaction vessel) where it is mixed with steam to generate 
solid uranyl fluoride (UO2F2). This powder then moves 
through the vessel to react with hydrogen gas (H2), which 
removes the fluoride. A chemical reduction takes the 
uranium to a pure microcrystalline uranium dioxide.
Wet processes inject UF6 into water to form a particu­
late slurry. Either ammonium carbonate [(NH4)2CO3] 
or ammonia (NH3) is added to this mixture to form 
ammonium uranyl carbonate (AUC) or ammonium 
diuranate (ADU). The slurry in each case is filtered, dried 
and heated to form pure UO2 in a reducing atmosphere. 
Wet methods are more complex and produce more wastes.
Downblending operations
Downblending is the process whereby highly enriched 
uranium is processed to reduce its concentration of U-235 
to levels suitable for use in commercial power plants. 
The resulting low enriched uranium (LEU) is no longer 
suitable for use in nuclear weapons and can be used for 
peaceful purposes. Megatons to Megawatts is a program 
that has been in operation since 1995 in which the 
U.S. government and industry partners, including The 
Babcock & Wilcox Company (B&W), have downblended 
U.S. and Russian weapons-grade uranium to LEU. By 
2013 the equivalent of 20,000 nuclear warheads had been 
downblended into commercial nuclear fuel. This fuel could 
produce enough electricity to meet the demand for a city 
the size of Boston for approximately 600 years.
Pellets
The UO2 powder is the primary constituent of nuclear 
fuel pellets. This powder is typically conditioned prior 
to pelletizing. Powders may require blending to ensure 
uniformity in terms of particle size and surface area. 
Also, U3O8 may be added to ensure microstructure and 
pellet density. Burnable absorbers (e.g., gadolinia or erbia) 
and pore-formers and binders may also need to be added.
In the pelletizing process, the enhanced UO2 powder 
is typically blended and sieved to form a homogeneous 
lot of about two tons. A pore-forming agent and recycled 
U3O8 are added to this blend. These materials are added 
in a ratio that attains the desired sintering density while 
optimizing pellet microstructure.
After blending, the powder is fed into dies and 
pressed biaxially into cylindrical pellet form. Pressing 
is performed using a reciprocating hydraulic or rotary 
unit. The press tonnage is set to provide a green (not yet 
sintered) pellet with high mechanical strength.
The next step, sintering, involves heating the pressed 
pellets in a furnace with a dry hydrogen atmosphere. The 
thermal cycle includes a sintering period of approximately 
4.5 hours at 3180F (1749C). The pellets are then centerless 
ground to their final dimensions. The final step is a visual 
inspection of the fuel pellets for any indication of cracks or 
surface irregularities. Scrap from this step is fed back into 
an earlier stage of the process. The resulting fuel pellets 
are shown in Fig. 5. Selected thermophysical properties 
of the final fuel pellets are summarized in Table 2.
As an alternative to mixing gadolinia or erbia into the 
uranium oxide material, a boron coating can be added to 
the outer surface of the pellet as a poison for reactivity 
control. Most pressurized water reactor (PWR) fuel now 
made in the U.S. uses boron-coated pellets.
Cladding
Zirconium forms the basis for commercial nuclear fuel 
rods. Zirconium-based alloys with improved corrosion 
performance allow for higher discharge burnups and are 
in widespread use in the U.S. and Europe. To create the 
fuel rod, the qualified material is first reduced in cold 
pilger (tube drawing) mills. An initial breakdown pass 
is performed to produce tubing near the required size. 
This is followed by a second and third pass to achieve the 
target dimensions. After each pass, the tubing is rinsed 
and dried.
The cladding is then heat treated in a high vacuum 
oven, which keeps the temperature uniform along the 
tube length. Subsequently, the material is cut to length. 
The outer surfaces are given a final polish and the tubes 
are rinsed. A final inspection is then performed. This 
includes an ultrasonic inspection to verify dimensions and 
to check for internal defects, and a visual examination 
with backlighting to identify surface irregularities.

Tube length, perpendicularity and straightness are 
then verified. Several laboratory samples are taken from 
each production lot to verify chemical composition and 
mechanical properties.
Fuel rods
Fuel rod manufacture begins with the zirconium alloy 
tubing/cladding previously discussed and includes the 
components shown in Fig. 6 (expanded view of fuel rod). 
Each cladding segment is identified with a unique serial 
number. The serial number is verified at every step of the 
fuel rod fabrication process. Subcomponent and process 
quality data are traceable by this number.
Cladding dimensions are sample inspected prior to 
being released for fuel rod production. Complete visual 
and tactile inspections are performed as the cladding 
enters the production line. A blast of dry air is passed 
through the cladding to remove any foreign material.
The fuel pellets containing the proper U-235 content 
per rod are weighed; this weight is recorded for each rod. 
The stack of pellets is visually examined for pellet quality 
and length. The fuel column is then inserted into the 
cladding. At this point, the lower end cap is resistance 
welded to the cladding.
A second check of the fuel column length is performed 
Fig. 6  Typical fuel rod assembly.
by seating the pellets against the lower end of the rod 
and measuring the distance between the top of the pellet 
column and the open upper end of the cladding. The 
upper plenum spring is installed. The upper end of the 
cladding is then inserted into a weld chamber where the 
rod is evacuated, pressurized with helium, and resistance 
welded. Pressurized helium ensures the mechanical and 
heat transfer properties of the fuel rod during its initial 
time in the reactor.
The sealed rods are then transferred to a scanner. 
Here, the rods are exposed to a neutron source. The result­
ing activity is measured and analyzed to nondestructively 
verify the fuel column integrity, length, and the enrich­
ment of the pellets. Next, the rods are transferred by 
groups for helium leak testing. This is a functional test 
of the cladding and end cap welds to verify rod sealing.
A final visual, tactile, and dimensional inspection 
is performed on each rod. The rods are then stored for 
subsequent fuel assembly fabrication.
Assembly
The upper and lower grids for fuel assemblies are typi­
cally fabricated from age-hardened nickel alloy (Inconel). 
In some designs, the upper grid may be fabricated from 
corrosion-resistant zironium alloys. The intermediate 
spacer grids are made from corrosion-resistant zirconium 
alloys. Strips of the grid alloy are stamped to form the 
detailed configurations required for contact points, 
springs and other attributes. After stamping, the strips 
are inspected and stored until released for production.
To assemble the spacer grids, the various types of 
strips are placed into an array forming a grid. Each grid 
is numbered and traceability information is recorded. 
After assembly, the grid is laser welded at each strip 
intersection. Inconel and zircaloy grids are laser welded 
in an inert atmosphere.
Inspection personnel visually examine the more than 
500 welds of each grid. Cell dimensions are checked by an 
automatic measuring system. (See Fig. 7.) Quality data 
is traceable back to the grid serial number.
The grids are installed into fixtures that secure them 
in the proper location. Next, control rod guide tubes are 
inserted through the grids. The grids are then secured 
to the guide tubes by resistance welding. The guide tubes 
and grids form the structural cage of the fuel assembly. 
The fuel rods are then inserted into the grids. The fuel 
rod serial number is scanned prior to loading each rod 
to verify that the correct rod is loaded into the proper 
location. The upper and lower end fittings are installed 
upon completion of rod loading.
Once the fabrication is completed, the fuel assembly 
is placed on a transfer cart, which is equipped to lift it 
to the vertical position. The assembly is then removed 
from the fixture and subsequent handling is done in the 
vertical orientation. (See Fig. 8.)
The fuel assembly dimensions are then checked in 
a vertical envelope gauge. Sensors verify straightness, 
twist, bow, and overall length dimensions in free standing 
and restrained positions. Gauges measure the distances 
between adjacent fuel rods at multiple axial locations 
along the length of the assembly; the data are compared 
to specifications. The assembly is then transferred to a 
pit, where a master control rod gauge is inserted into

the fuel assembly guide thimbles. This insertion verifies 
guide thimble alignment and ensures that the thimbles 
do not restrict control rod insertion.
A final visual inspection is performed using high 
intensity lights. (See Fig. 9.) The assembly is cleaned and 
sealed in a plastic sheath; it is now ready for storage or 
shipment to a reactor site.
Fuel assemblies are shipped to the reactor site in 
specially designed and licensed containers. (See Fig. 10.) 
The fuel bundle is installed by crane into the container 
(which typically holds either one or two bundles) in the 
vertical position and secured to a strong-back which 
prevents bowing or twisting of the assembly during 
subsequent movements of the shipping container. Next, 
the container is lowered to a horizontal position and 
secured. Shock indicators, mounted to the container, 
measure shipment-induced shock. The indicators trip 
if exposed to excessive acceleration forces and these 
indicators can be viewed at the site prior to opening the 
container.
Small modular reactor fuel assembly
Small modular reactors (SMR) are being developed as 
an alternative to traditional large central station nuclear 
power plants. (See Chapter 47.) The mPower™ SMR 
features an integral pressurized water reactor (iPWR) 
which uses a standard 17 × 17 fuel assembly lattice and 
control rod pattern, but is slightly shorter in fuel column 
length [95 in. (2413 mm) compared to the standard 168 
in. (4267 mm)].
Plant Operations
Most U.S. power reactors operate for a planned period 
of between one and two years before the reactivity of the 
nuclear fuel is depleted and the unit must be reloaded with 
fresh fuel. Because only part of the fuel is replaced during 
the shutdown, this is referred to as batch refueling. In 
some reactors, such as the Canadian (CANDU®) design,

48-8
Steam 42 / Nuclear Fuels
The Babcock & Wilcox Company
a continuous refueling mode, which does not require 
reactor shutdown, is used.
Most PWR operating cycles were originally designed 
for annual refueling, which equates to replacing 
approximately one third of the fuel assemblies at each 
outage. As operating experience has been gained and 
both industry- and government-sponsored test programs 
have confirmed the higher burnup capability of the 
existing and upgraded designs, the trend has shifted to 
18- or 24-month refueling cycles. Although fuel costs are 
higher, the longer refueling cycle is cost effective due to 
reductions in the number of refueling outages, licensing 
submittals and replacement power cost. Furthermore, 
the increased burnup capability of the fuel has permitted 
subsequent batch size reductions with longer cycle times. 
Today, units on 18-month cycles are loaded with batch 
sizes once used for annual cycles. In addition to adopting 
18- or 24-month cycles, most [PWR and boiling water 
reactor (BWR)] plants have converted from the out/in 
shuffle scheme to a checkerboard scheme, which spreads 
the fresh fuel homogenously throughout the core, because 
of its flexibility in accommodating the batch size and 
enrichment changes. Fresh fuel assemblies are also no 
longer placed in core periphery positions in order to lower 
the neutron fluence and protect the reactor vessel from 
its harmful effects.
The mPower SMR is designed to have up to a four-year 
fuel cycle. Upon completion of a four-year operating cycle, 
the entire fuel load would be replaced. The increased plant 
availability and resulting capacity factor have shown to 
be more beneficial than a shorter operating cycle, where 
fuel bundle shuffling would be utilized.
As nuclear fuel is consumed, its characteristics change. 
Four major issues are burnup dependent: dimensional 
and structural changes, cladding water-side corrosion 
and hydriding, fission gas release, and pellet cladding 
interaction. Ongoing performance monitoring programs 
have collected data to assess these phenomena. To date, 
assembly burnups of greater than 70,000 MWd/tmU have 
been attained.
Dimensional and structural changes
Dimensional and structural changes primarily include 
irradiation growth of the fuel rods and fuel assembly, hold-
down spring relaxation and fuel rod bow. Fuel assembly 
growth is caused by irradiation-induced growth of the 
guide tubes in the assembly and the stresses induced in 
the guide tubes through the interaction with fuel rods 
and grids. Fuel rod growth has been comparable to fuel 
assembly growth because the fuel rod and assembly guide 
tubes are made of similar materials, and pellet-cladding 
interaction (PCI) within the fuel rods has not shown any 
tendency to cause mechanically induced growth in the 
fuel rods.
Other dimensional and structural changes, including 
changes in the fuel rod diameter and fuel density, can occur 
in the fuel assembly and its components with continued 
irradiation. Although the database on these phenomena 
indicates no life-limiting constraints, the phenomena can 
have combined effects on overall rod performance and 
susceptibility to other failure mechanisms.
Cladding water-side corrosion and hydriding
Under reactor operating conditions, the fuel rod clad­
ding acquires a thin, adherent oxide layer early in life. 
After this initial film is established, the extent of further 
water-side corrosion is a complex function of in-reactor 
residence time, neutron fluence, local flow conditions, 
and coolant temperature and water chemistry. However, 
increasing data variability has been observed for fuel rods 
with burnups greater than 35,000 MWd/tmU. The U.S. 
Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) has established 
corrosion and oxide buildup as life limiting. The industry 
has implemented advanced alloys in response such that 
virtually all reactors in the U.S. use an advanced alloy.
Fission gas release
If not accounted for in the fuel rod design, release of 
fission gas from the fuel at high burnup and high power 
levels can cause high internal fuel rod pressure. Levels

of fission gas release from PWR fuel rods operated at 
normal linear heat rates to burnups of 50,000 MWd/
tmU have been low, averaging less than 5%. However, the 
NRC has made fission gas release a life-limiting effect. 
Fuel cycle designs and core peaking limits are impacted 
by fission gas release licensing analyses.
Pellet-cladding interaction
Pellet-cladding interaction (PCI) is a broad category of 
events involving contact between the fuel pellets and the 
cladding. The most common instance of PCI that causes 
loss of cladding integrity through mechanical means is 
when changes in power level occur too abruptly in the fuel 
rod and the resulting stress causes cladding failure. This 
has led to power maneuvering guidelines in commercial 
nuclear reactors. The pre-load of helium in fuel rods is 
done to prevent PCI.

Spent Fuel and Nuclear Waste Management
Extreme care and detailed handling procedures are 
required to remove the spent fuel assemblies for disposi­
tion. (See Chapter 52.) During their removal from the 
reactor core and near-term storage in spent fuel pools, 
water serves as both a shielding and a cooling medium. 
The spent fuel assemblies are kept in the spent fuel pool 
at the reactor site until the radioactive decay and heat 
generation have declined sufficiently for on-site storage 
or for safe transportation and processing. The fuel can 
then be disposed of directly (open cycle) or reprocessed 
(closed cycle) to recover 97% of the material. (See Chapter 
53.) Essentially all commercial reactor fuel in the U.S. to 
date has been stored on site at the nuclear reactor which 
produced it. Dry storage on the reactor site is commonly 
used after the assemblies become sufficiently low in heat 
production to allow for passive cooling by radiant heating.

The Babcock & Wilcox Company
Nuclear reactors are powered by fuel that contains 
fissile material. The relatively low cost of nuclear fuel per 
unit of energy is one of the primary reasons that utilities 
will opt to use nuclear power rather than fossil fuels for 
electricity generation. Nuclear fuel is a compact source 
of energy, producing negligible adverse environmental 
effects and small amounts of residual waste products. 
In some countries spent nuclear fuel is reprocessed to 
reclaim the uranium and plutonium in the discharged fuel 
assemblies. By reprocessing, about 97% of the materials 
in the spent fuel assembly can be reused.
The use of uranium as an energy source for steam and 
power generation involves a number of steps collectively 
referred to as the nuclear fuel cycle. These steps include 
mining and milling, conversion, enrichment, pelletizing, 
encapsulation in zirconium alloy fuel rods, assembly 
into fuel bundles, power production, and disposal. If 
the spent fuel is not reprocessed, the cycle is referred 
to as a once-through or open fuel cycle. When the fuel is 
reprocessed, it goes through a closed fuel cycle. Fig. 1 
provides an overview of the closed nuclear fuel cycle from 
the mining of the uranium ore to disposal. An open fuel 
cycle is currently the method utilized in the United States 
(U.S.). Fuel is stored in cooling pools until such time that 
it can be safely stored on site in dry casks. Chapter 53 
addresses the important issue of disposal in more depth.
Nuclear Reactor Fuel Sources
Uranium
Uranium (U) is the basic raw material of the nuclear 
power industry. It is a heavy, slightly radioactive element 
with an atomic number of 92. Uranium is the heaviest 
element that is found naturally in more than trace 
quantities in the earth’s crust.
Uranium ore deposits are located throughout the world 
and are dominated by Kazakhstan, Canada, Australia, 
Niger and Namibia. (See Table 1.) Russia, South Africa, 
Brazil and the U.S. also have substantial uranium ore 
deposits and production capabilities. The current reason­
ably assured resources (known deposits of such a size, 
grade and configuration that they are recoverable with 
proven technology at costs of U.S. $130/kg U or less) are 
approximately 5,400,000 tonnes U. These deposits have 
a high probability of commercial recovery.
Uranium is a highly reactive metal with three principal 
valences: +3, +4 and +6. It has three crystalline phases 
and melts at 2070F (1132C). In the alpha (a) phase, it is

reasonably ductile and can be fabricated by standard met­
alworking techniques. Because small uranium particles 
or chips are highly pyrophoric (capable of spontaneous 
combustion when exposed to air), machining operations 
and scrap storage require special precautions, such as 
the use of a coolant or an inert atmosphere.
Isotopes and the fundamentals of nuclear physics are 
discussed in Chapter 49. Natural uranium is a mixture of 
three isotopes: uranium-234 (U-234) 0.01%, uranium-235 
(U-235) 0.71%, and uranium-238 (U-238) 99.28%. U-234 
is present in small amounts and is not significant. U-235 
is a fissionable isotope and U-238 is known as a fertile 
isotope which can be transmuted to a fissionable material.
These isotopes are slightly radioactive and emit alpha 
particles. Because natural uranium has a relatively long 
half-life, a minimum of precaution is required when 
handling it. However, it is chemically toxic and must not 
be ingested. In handling areas, levels of airborne uranium 
must be minimized.
U-235 is fissionable because its nucleus can absorb a 
neutron, become unstable and split into multiple pieces. 
When 1 gram of U-235 fissions, the heat released is 
equivalent to approximately 1 MWd [24,000 kWh (82 × 
106 Btu)]. When one short ton of U-235 fissions, the heat 
released is equivalent to 22 × 109 kWh or 75 × 1012 Btu, 
which equals the energy contained in approximately 3 
million tons of coal.
By itself, U-238 cannot sustain a nuclear chain 
reaction, but absorption of a high energy neutron can 
cause it to fission. Sufficient U-235 must be present to 
initiate the fission process and drive the chain reaction. 
When exposed to neutrons in a nuclear reactor, the 
U-238 nucleus will capture a neutron and is transformed 
into plutonium-239 (Pu-239), a fissile isotope. Pu-239 
is capable of sustaining a chain reaction of fissions as 
this process produces a similar number of free neutrons 
as U-235. U-238 is therefore considered to be fertile 
because of this transmutable property. U-238 is 140 times 
more abundant in nature than U-235 and is the main 
component of nuclear fuel.
Plutonium
Although trace quantities of plutonium are found 
in nature, most plutonium is made from U-238 trans­
mutation. All commercial plutonium is made by this 
transmutation process.
Plutonium is a radioactive element with an atomic 
number of 94. Although it is classified as a metal, its

electrical and thermal conductivities are relatively low, 
making it more like a ceramic material in some ways. 
Plutonium has a melting point of 1184F (640C), but it 
Fig. 1  Closed nuclear fuel cycle.
must be melted in a vacuum or inert atmosphere because 
it is chemically very reactive. It has complicated chemical 
properties, with five valence states ranging from +2 
to +6. Plutonium also has complicated metallurgical 
properties and is the only element with six allotropes 
(different physical forms, such as charcoal and diamond 
forms of carbon). A seventh allotrope exists at a specific 
temperature and temperature range.
The 15 known isotopes of plutonium range in atomic 
weight from 232 to 246. All are radioactive, decaying 
to form stable isotopes of elements such as bismuth and 
lead. Pu-239 is the most common isotope of plutonium 
and is the primary product of fast breeder reactors which 
are specially designed to produce more fuel than they 
use. Plutonium generated in commercial power reactors 
contains substantial amounts of isotopes with mass 
numbers greater than 239.
Thorium
Although uranium is the basic nuclear power fuel, 
enormous natural reserves of thorium are also available. 
Thorium contains no fissionable isotope like U-235; it is 
primarily a fertile material. The absorption of neutrons 
within a nuclear reactor converts thorium to U-233. While 
this is another fissile uranium isotope, it does not occur

in natural uranium. Thorium may be used in conjunction 
with U-235 to enlarge the available fissile resources for 
nuclear fuel.
Reserves of thorium, available as thorium oxide 
(ThO2), are estimated to exceed half a million tons. A 
large portion of these resources occurs as monazite sand, 
which is found in India, Brazil and the U.S. Thorium 
reserves in the U.S. are estimated at 100,000 tons of 
thorium oxide equivalent.
While developing thorium fuel for nuclear power 
continues to remain a research topic, world nuclear 
production and development is centered around the 
uranium-plutonium cycle because of its cost advantage 
and abundance compared to thorium.
Uranium Extraction, Enrichment 
and Conversion
The method of uranium ore removal from the ground 
depends upon the characteristics of the deposit. Open 
pit mining is used when the uranium ore is found near 
the surface, typically less than 330 ft (100 m). At greater 
depths, underground mining methods are employed. 
Some locations allow uranium to be dissolved by pumping 
solutions underground, transporting it above ground, and 
then extracting the dissolved uranium.
A number of steps are required to extract uranium 
concentrate from the ore and to prepare the uranium for 
use in fabricating fuel pellets for commercial reactors. As 
shown in Fig. 1, these initial steps in the fuel cycle include 
milling, conversion to uranium hexafluoride (UF6), 
enrichment, and conversion to uranium dioxide (UO2).
Milling
The function of uranium milling is to extract the 
uranium from the ore, which contains on the average 
about 5 lb (2.3 kg) of uranium per ton or about 0.25%. 
The ore is crushed and is then leached with an acid or 
alkaline reagent to dissolve the uranium which, in turn, 
is recovered from the solution by solvent extraction or ion 
exchange techniques. Excess water is removed by calcin­
ing, or roasting. The resultant product, known in the 
industry as yellowcake, is a crude uranium concentrate 
containing from 70 to 90% U3O8.
Conversion to UF6
For the purpose of enrichment, the uranium in yel­
lowcake must be converted into UF6. Fig. 2 illustrates 
the process, in which the essential steps are:
1.	 The U3O8 feed is reduced to raw UO2 at 550 to 650C 
with hydrogen or dissociated ammonia in the first 
converter.
2.	 The raw UO2 is converted to UF4 at 450 to 650C with 
anhydrous hydrogen fluoride (HF) gas in the second 
converter.
3.	 The UF4 is converted to crude UF6 at 350 to 500C with 
elemental fluorine in the last converter.
The final step is fractional distillation for the removal 
of impurities, principally molybdenum and vanadium. 
The UF6 product meets the applicable specifications for 
impurities allowable in uranium hexafluoride delivered 
for enrichment in the separation plants.
Enrichment
Prior to fabrication into fuel assemblies, the uranium 
must be enriched to the desired concentration of the fis­
sionable isotope, U-235. This is accomplished in gaseous 
diffusion plants which are designed to separate isotopes 
by using the principles of gas kinetics, or by using fast 
spinning cylinders in a centrifuge process.
In a mixture of two gases (U-238 and U-235 hexafluo­
ride), molecules of the lighter gas (235UF6) travel faster and 
strike the walls of the containing vessels more frequently 
than do the molecules of the heavier gas (238UF6). If the 
wall of the vessel is permeable, the lighter molecules will 
diffuse faster, relative to their concentration, than the 
heavier molecules. The degree of separation attainable 
in this manner is very small and the process must be 
repeated many times before a practical enrichment can be 
obtained. Therefore, a gaseous diffusion plant consists of 
hundreds of stages connected in series in an arrangement 
known as a diffusion cascade.
Each diffusion stage consists of a chamber divided 
into two zones by a finely porous, thin barrier. The gas 
mixture enters one zone, which is maintained at a higher 
pressure than the other. Conditions are adjusted so that 
part of the gas diffuses through the barrier into the lower 
pressure zone and then is directed to the next stage up 
the cascade. The remainder flows from the high pressure 
zone to the next stage down the cascade. The uranium 
hexafluoride gas stream diffusing through the barrier 
is very slightly enriched in the U-235 isotope; the other 
stream is very slightly depleted in that isotope.
Fig. 3 illustrates the sequence of operations in the 
cascade. Stages are arranged in a countercurrent 
cascade similar to a distillation column. At each stage, 
a pump compresses the gas from the pressure on the 
downstream side of the diffusion barrier to the pressure 
on the upstream side and a cooler removes the heat of 
compression.
The natural uranium feed enters the cascade at 
an intermediate point. The gas becomes increasingly 
enriched as it progresses up the cascade. The enriched 
uranium product is withdrawn at some stage above the 
feed point, depending on the degree of enrichment desired. 
Depleted uranium (known as tails) is withdrawn from 
the base of the cascade and held in storage.
